review_title: Great people, but little organizational support.
job_title: Network Support Technician in Fayetteville, AR
pros:
Get access to managed network switches, normally costing $2000+, plus a lot of freedom and time to use them to study for your networking certifications (they don't mind you taking a switch or two out of the stock to use for studying provided you don't let it leave the building without permission).

Honestly, I love the people I work with. They make me look forward to going to work.

Management has been some of the most supportive I have ever had.
cons:
This seems like an easy job for part-timers (students) until you actually start doing it. The ramp-up time is at least 6 months. Couple this with minimum wage pay, bringing with it high turnover. This leads to you, should you stay at least 1 year, having to train/help train multiple co-workers, with the costs of training the previous ones just, say, 4 months ago, sunk. This job should really be a full-time position, paying at least $18 an hour.

No opportunities for career advancement outside the normal job application submission process, and related outside competition.

review_title: Not the best, not the worst.
pros: Quite a bit of paid time off. Flexibility in work schedule depending on supervisor.
cons: Not many clear pathways upward.

job_title: Honors College Peer Mentor in Fayetteville, AR
pros: Great staff to work along

pros: Working for the U of A provides security, monthly accrual of sick and PTO time, and major holidays off. It's a great place to work if you get into the right department. Health, vision, dental, and life insurance and 4O1K available. The plans are pretty basic.
cons: Parking is difficult and you have to purchase a parking pass for work. Some of the older buildings are not as clean and kept up. There are pay restrictions in place on some positions so you can't negotiate salary. If you start working after July 1, you are not eligible for a raise until the following fiscal year.

review_title: Great for Low Stress, Bad If You Want Better Compensation

review_title: Working within the program and students in wonderful, departmental and college  support of program needs is frustrating.
pros: The univeristy where I work offers a number of graduate programs that allow adults of continue their educations.  These opportunities allow graduates to increase their professional growth, portability and income.
cons: Each college is its own community.  Some of the procedures, requirements, and practices of each college can be vastly different.  Programs that do not have a strong link to the colleges larger program or that is not the area of expertise for the dean often have to struggle to get the support and resources that they need to meet the students needs within their program.

review_title: Pay More Attention on Leaders in your own WorkPlace!!!
job_title: Project\Program Manager in Little Rock, AR
pros: Time off given to non-classified employees is great 22 days to start, two weeks sick time, and 12 paid holidays (which iincludes your birthday)
cons: distance you have to walk from car to get to the building you work in, don't get much training unless you pay for it yourself, have to go outside of your building to go to the restroom.  It's not pleasant when it's wintertime.

pros: As a GA I was very well taken care of.  It is the most rewarding place to work as a GA on UALR campus if you are a business major.  Everyone seems to be more like a family here and works together well overall.
cons: Many of the projects I was tasked took lots of time and the consultants you work with sometimes don't understand this and get impatient.

review_title: Great work. Management could be improved.
job_title: Assistant Professor in Little Rock, AR
pros: The graduate students that I teach are terrific. They are bright and motivated. The topics I work on are interesting. They give me a lot of latitude regarding what I teach.
cons: My cons are only specific to my unit. The management of our unit could use some work. We need a faculty department chair. The upper management should be more sympathetic to the needs of the faculty, and be more faculty centered, and less student centered. The students are extremely coddled. The students need to be required to be more independent.

job_title: EVersity Employee in Little Rock, AR
pros: I love working here. The people are great, the environment beautiful.  Our office is nestled in a park like environment.  Lots of trees.  Don Bobbitt is an excellent leader and so is Michael Moore. They are very open and approachable.  They value their employees and create a work environment that allows for creativity and collaboration.
cons: There are no negatives I can think of for working at the UA System office. I have enjoyed the experience thus far.

pros: There is no better place than Northwest Arkansas and no better people to work with.  I enjoyed coming to work every day and walked away with life-long friendships.
cons: The pay isn't incredible, but what can you expect from a public university?  It was more about the impact I felt I had made at the end of each day than the pay I received.

review_title: Overall - a good university to work at
job_title: Assistant Professor in Fort Smith, AR
pros: Good people who really care about others, mostly positive workplace, realitstic expectations, good facilities, located in a nice family setting (Fort Smith)
cons: Still becoming a regional university and coming out of its community college roots, lack of vision from senior administration, too many mid-level managers hired recently has drained support from faculty, no pay raises in past four years, little support for research.

cons: The salaries are 20% less than one could make in a similar job in the private sector.  Tenure system keeps too many professors there who should have retired.

pros: Great group of people working there.  Benefits are excellent.
cons: Director does not trust employees to make decisions and gets involved in lower level decision making rather than focusing on long-term goals.  Very critical of mistakes.  Keeps reducing staffing levels to save money.

pros: Flexibility in balancing work and home is wonderful.  The benefits are great!
cons: Pay is below what you would make in industry.  Not much room to grow in your career.

pros: I enjoy the many benefits working at the University. Medical, Vision, Dental, tuition discount and retirement. I also work in a small department which has a family atmosphere.
cons: Parking is probably the biggest grip on campus. You have to pay to park then take a long hike.
